G.L. c. 208.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208 and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a domestic relations matter involving custody, parenting time, and related orders concerning minor children of the parties.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208 and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a domestic relations matter involving custody, parenting time, and related orders concerning minor children of the parties.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 5, 28..proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior custody order was entered in this Court and the parties and children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 5, 28.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), which authorize the Court to modify existing custody and visitation orders upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), which authorize the Court to modify existing custody and visitation orders upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard, as codified in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and elaborated in cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843–844, focuses on the child’s welfare, emotional health, stability, and the ability of each parent to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Determine that modification of the 2022 Order is necessary to serve the best interests of the minor children, Emily and Jacob, consistent with G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590; Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009); Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); and related precedent;

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that: a. A custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment; and b. The paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The case clearly supports part (a): it states that to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must show a ‘material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment,’ and it applies that standard in affirming denial of a modification. The opinion, however, concerns modification of support and alimony, not custody or parenting time, and it does not explicitly articulate the ‘paramount best interests of the child’ standard, though it does mention ‘the benefit of the children’ as a factor. Thus it is solid authority for the material-change requirement and only indirect support for the best-interests language and for custody/parenting-time specifically.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that: a. A custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment; and b. The paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for custody determinations, emphasizing that domestic violence and its effect on the child must be explicitly considered, but it does not clearly recite the general "material and substantial change in circumstances" standard for modification of prior custody or parenting-time orders. While the court implicitly applies a best‑interests framework, the case is focused on reversing and remanding an initial custody judgment, not setting out or applying the doctrinal standard for modifying an existing judgment upon changed circumstances. Therefore it does not cleanly support either part (a) or (b) as a clear statement of those general rules.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. ... We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm. ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that: a. A custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment; and b. The paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly declines to consider the father’s argument that the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (the modification standard) should apply, finding that issue waived. Thus it does not apply or affirm the material-and-substantial-change requirement for modifying existing custody or parenting-time orders. It does, however, strongly reaffirm that the paramount consideration in custody determinations is the best interests of the child—but because the proposition is conjunctive (a and b), the case as a whole does not support the full proposition as stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… [T]he ‘best interests’ standard… has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation.”}

Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that: a. A custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment; and b. The paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009).support_reasoning: This opinion is a first-degree murder case addressing evidentiary, investigatory, and prosecutorial issues; it does not involve custody, parenting time, or modification of family-law orders. There is no discussion of standards for modifying custody/parenting time based on a material and substantial change in circumstances or of the best interests of the child as a paramount consideration. Therefore, it does not support the cited family-law proposition.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that: a. A custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment; and b. The paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 and states that a custody judgment may be modified upon a finding of a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and that the modification must be “necessary in the best interests of the children.” It also reaffirms that, in both initial custody awards and modifications, “the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.” This directly tracks both parts (a) and (b) of the proposition regarding Massachusetts custody modification standards and the paramountcy of the child’s best interests.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that: a. A custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment; and b. The paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly supports part (b): it expressly states that in deciding custody, the court’s "overriding concern" must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and welfare, and it applies that standard. However, the case does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting time judgment based on a material and substantial change in circumstances; it is reviewing an initial custody and visitation determination made after trial. Because the proposition is conjunctive (a and b), and part (a) is not discussed, the case does not fully support the claimed proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). Heard v. Heard, 323 Mass. 357, 375-377 (1948). Clifford v. Clifford, 354 Mass. 545, 548 (1968) ("sole question" is what is best for children’s welfare).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843\u20138.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard, as codified in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and elaborated in cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843–844, focuses on the child’s welfare, emotional health, stability, and the ability of each parent to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard, as codified in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and elaborated in cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843–844, focuses on the child’s welfare, emotional health, stability, and the ability of each parent to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. See also Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the “best interests of the child” standard in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and the removal statute to a holistic inquiry into the child’s welfare, including emotional and developmental needs, stability and quality of life, and the impact on the relationship with the noncustodial parent. The court emphasizes that best interests are “paramount,” discusses the children’s welfare and emotional needs, and directly considers the impact on the father–child relationship, which aligns with the proposition’s description of the standard.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt:
“The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.

… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard, as codified in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and elaborated in cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 843–844, focuses on the child’s welfare, emotional health, stability, and the ability of each parent to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. See also Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (1986).
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion is a care and protection / parental unfitness case under G.L. c. 119, not a G.L. c. 208, § 31 custody‑between‑parents case. While it does refer to the “best interests” of the children and emphasizes their need for a stable and safe environment, it does not articulate the § 31 best‑interests factors such as emotional health, stability in a comparative-custody sense, or each parent’s ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. The case is more about parental unfitness versus State custody than the inter‑parental best‑interests standard described in the proposition, so it only indirectly relates and does not clearly support that specific formulation.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Based on these subsidiary findings relating to the best interests of the children and the ability of the parents to care and provide for the children, the judge found that returning the children to their parents would negatively affect the progress the parents had made in their own relationship and that no future time had been established indicating when, if ever, the parents would be able to care for their children. He concluded, therefore, that the parents were currently unfit to care for the children and ordered the children committed to the permanent custody of the department.”
